summary: This document is an email from an anonymous victim to an unspecified recipient, recounting being sexually assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein when she was barely 18 years old at a NYC restaurant. The victim describes seeing Epstein's face on the news months prior and connecting it to her assault, and mentions Ghislaine Maxwell possibly being present. She expresses a desire to help but lacks proof and details.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Identified by the victim as the person who sexually assaulted her when she was barely 18 years old at a NYC restaurant.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned by the victim as possibly being present at the assault, recalling a 'woman' there along with other men and girls.

connections.description: The victim recalls a 'woman' being present at the assault alongside Epstein and other men, and later speculates this woman could have been Maxwell.
The victim states she was sexually assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein when she was barely 18 years old.

events.title: Sexual assault in NYC restaurant
events.description: The victim recounts being sexually assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein when she was barely 18 years old at a NYC restaurant. She mentions other girls and a woman (possibly Ghislaine Maxwell) being present.

events.title: Victim's email disclosure
events.description: The victim sends an email disclosing her assault by Epstein, prompted by seeing his face on the news months earlier. She expresses uncertainty about being helpful due to lack of proof and faded memory details.

keyFacts: An anonymous victim states she was sexually assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein when she was barely 18 years old at a NYC restaurant.
The victim recalls other girls and a woman being present at the assault, and speculates the woman could have been Ghislaine Maxwell.
The victim connected the assault to Epstein only after seeing his face on the news months prior to sending this email in July 2020.
The victim describes being traumatized and initially too scared to come forward, and later erasing memories and associations from that part of her life.
The victim offers to help but acknowledges she lacks proof and cannot remember key details like the name of the friend who invited her or the exact venue.
